description: From Latin fastīdiōsus (“passive: that feels disgust, disdainful, scornful, fastidious; active: that causes disgust, disgusting, loathsome”), from fastīdium (“a loathing, aversion, disgust, niceness of taste, daintiness, etc.”), perhaps for *fastutidium, from fastus (“disdain, haughtiness, arrogance, disgust”) + taedium (“disgust”). Cf. French fastidieux.

adjectives.description: fastidious (comparative more fastidious, superlative most fastidious)

entries.meaning: Excessively particular, demanding, or fussy about details, especially about tidiness and cleanliness.
examples: Synonyms: exacting, fussy, meticulous, niggly, pernickety; see also Thesaurus:fastidious

entries.meaning: Overly concerned about tidiness and cleanliness.
Difficult to please; quick to find fault.
